content:
Several lawsuits raise big questions about the scope of presidential power

SOON AFTER President Donald Trump declared a national emergency on February 15th to fund the construction of a wall on America’s southern border he said, “I didn’t need to do this, but I’d rather do [the wall] much faster”. Deepak Gupta, a lawyer who argues before the Supreme Court, suggested that lawyers challenging Mr Trump’s decision consider quoting the president's own words against him “on page 1” of their court filings. 

In the days since, Mr Trump's declaration has triggered a wave of legal challenges. The lawsuits raise fundamental questions about the scope of presidential power in America’s constitutional design. And they begin by making note of the mismatch between Mr Trump’s rhetoric and the purported “border security and humanitarian crisis” that, the according to the presidential proclamation, plagues America's boundary with Mexico.

But there is a technical reason why it may have been unnecessary for Mr Trump to declare an emergency—or at least to declare one as soon as he did. And it seems he was mistaken in his assumption that the declaration would help him build his wall “much faster”. That is because a large chunk of the roughly $8bn Mr Trump said he intends to spend on the wall has nothing to do with funding sources that are unlocked in the event of an emergency.  

The three lawsuits to spring up directly challenging Mr Trump’s national emergency press constitutional arguments against the aggrandisement of presidential power. The complaints from environmental groups, Texas landowners and 16 Democratic states, who say the reallocation of federal funds will harm their residents and economies, focus on Mr Trump’s usurpation of Congress’s “power of the purse” and draw on the Youngstown case from 1952 in which the Supreme Court chided Harry Truman for seizing the nation’s steel mills without legal authorisation. The president, Justice Hugo Black wrote, is not “a lawmaker”; when he acts in ways that thwart congressional will, Justice Robert Jackson added, a president’s power is “at its lowest ebb”. 

The lawsuits are less clear where they contest Mr Trump’s specific claims of authority under statutes that allow presidents to reallocate money toward emergency endeavours. But the lack of clarity is not entirely the fault of the plaintiffs: it follows from the administration’s skimpy accounting for its decision to commandeer several federal piggy banks. The White House fact sheet lays out three pools of money it hopes to shift toward the wall to top off the $1.375bn Congress gave for 55 miles of border fencing: $601m from the Treasury's asset-forfeiture funds, up to $2.5bn from Department of Defence (DoD) anti-drug funds (under title 10, section 284 of the federal code) and up to $3.6bn from DoD military construction projects (under title 10, section 2808).

The plaintiffs take issue with all of these moves. The 16 states, for example, say that whereas section 2808 appropriations must be “directly linked to a military installation”, wall-building has no direct connection to a project of America’s armed forces. They argue, too, that diverting dollars to the border wall does not satisfy the requirement in section 284 that funds must be directed to “counter drug activities” such as blocking “drug-smuggling corridors.” The White House will probably respond to these claims, but for now its reasoning is opaque. A separate lawsuit from the Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW) centres on the scant justification that accompanies the declaration and demands that the Department of Justice provide a full explanation under earlier Freedom of Information Act requests. 

One feature of the emergency declaration may save Mr Trump from immediate losses in court: only the last of the three pots of money requires the declaration of a national emergency. Presidents may spend the first two (if the diversions are appropriate and lawful) without any such announcement. And since the White House says it will tap into these funds “sequentially and as needed”, Mr Trump can begin spending up to $4.5bn on the wall before turning to any monies tied to his purported emergency. 

Why, then, did Mr Trump opt to fight this battle now, rather when he runs out of money and needs to tap the emergency funds? Perhaps he wanted to use the fight as a sign that he will do everything in his power to fulfil a campaign promise. The decision to force the issue of the legality of the emergency declaration now, well before emergency funds are tapped, also puts plaintiffs in a bind. In Alvarez v Trump , the Texas landowner case, Nayda Alvarez complains that if Mr Trump’s emergency is honoured, the “view from her back door will be of a large wall, rather than the river view that she currently enjoys”. But if Mr Trump can pay for the wall through Ms Alvarez’s backyard with the $1.375bn from Congress, or the $601bn from asset-forfeiture funds, the emergency is a non-issue. Courts may address narrow questions of statutory authority to reallocate money under section 284 and the asset-forfeiture fund but reject plaintiffs’ claims challenging the emergency declaration as not yet ripe for consideration. 

This may put the lawsuits on a slow course. But how will the courts rule when they consider Mr Trump’s emergency declaration? There is a fair chance one or more of the district court judges will side with the plaintiffs and block Mr Trump's emergency diversions. The president's luck could change in the circuit courts of appeal and at the Supreme Court, which last June upheld Mr Trump’s third version of a ban on travel from predominantly Muslim countries. The five conservative justices deferred to the administration’s judgment, as the judiciary typically does in matters of national security and immigration. 

But it is hard to say whether the Supreme Court will allow Mr Trump’s emergency. Stephen Vladeck of the University of Texas law school says “there are too many variables” to make a prediction about which cases will get to the Supreme Court or “the configuration in which they arrive”. He says that “the full legal contours of what he’s wrought” will not become clear any time soon. Josh Blackman of the South Texas College of Law says the lawsuits are premature given the step-by-step nature of the various funding mechanisms and procedural concerns involving standing and ripeness. The Supreme Court is unlikely to rule on them until after 2020, he says. If Mr Trump fails to win a second term, the cases against the emergency declaration “will vanish”—perhaps along with the idea that there ever was an emergency on the southern border at all.

奥巴马总统说："我认为，没有任何理由让我们不去抓住这个机会和这个时刻。"

但要实现这一愿景，实现我们大家所寻求的经济增长，则需要开启一个能使我们的经济在未来数十年中获得动力的必不可少的增长源泉。
But love without strength is incomplete. It is for you to  the paradox of duality and shift upward into integral crystalline vibration.

The richness of religious diversity must be  – whether it is for Maronites in Lebanon or the Copts in Egypt.
我们必须支持丰富的宗教多样性 - 无论是黎巴嫩的马龙教派还是埃及的科普特教派。
When the Supreme Court  the principle of affirmative action in 2003, I thought of my black students, of how hard they worked and all they had to overcome.
2003年，最高法院判决支持了《平权法案》的原则，我想起了我的黑人学生，想起了他们付出的艰苦努力，想起了他们需要克服的所有困难。

eg2: The jagged ramparts of the mainland and islands unsoiled by human footprints drift past, an endless drama wrought in ice and snow.
未被人类踏足的大陆和岛屿的粗糙的城墙在眼前漂过，一出永不落幕的戏剧在冰雪中生成。

Whether or not the legislation passes, it's a sign of the emotional turmoil that women like her have  in their communities.

Title: The legal battle over Donald Trump’s emergency declaration could be a long one

paperStatistics.desc: Several lawsuits raise big questions about the scope of presidential power
